But AMD is clapping back with more available PCIe lanes off the CPU, and what appears to be a more mature DDR5 memory controller. That is if the test notes are to be believed. Not content with only that, AMD has come after Intel in terms of core clocks, too. In their demo, at the end of the presentation, they showed off a pre-production 16-core Ryzen 7000 CPU, blazing along at 5.5 gigahertz in "Ghostwire: Tokyo," which matches the Core i9-12900KS' maximum boost clock. That alone is a massive improvement over AMD's current flagship, the 5950X, which manages 4.9 gigahertz max boost. And remember guys, this isn't a game. It's not even single threaded. AMD could have called it a day at that point, but no. They're coming at Intel with core level improvements, too, like AI acceleration instructions, though, exactly what they are and what they do, isn't yet known. What is known is that thanks in part to doubling the Level 2 cache on each core to one megabyte, AMD is claiming a 15% or greater per thread performance improvement in Cinebench R23. So if they can get multi-core clocks to stay high to match those single-core clocks, Intel may have to go completely back to the drawing board. Thankfully, AMD's new LGA-based socket, AM5, supports CPUs with TDPs of up to 170 Watts. So along with the switch to what AMD hints is an optimized version of TSMC's N5P process node, that shouldn't be an unreasonable goal especially with a good cooler. I mean, especially since there's coolers out there that are rated to handle Intel's 12900K, which is rated for 241 Watts. And from our testing, regularly blows right past that figure. Thanks to its extra power draw, the 12900K does manage to beat the 5950X in our testing during short renders, like the kind that AMD showed on stage, but the best we've seen is a 15% lead the other way for AMD in a much longer test. As for AMD's Ryzen 7000 demo, they showed the 16-core Ryzen 7000 chip finishing 31% faster than the Core i9-12900K. This is big. That was in a short test too, right, Anthony? - Oh yeah. - Woo. Interestingly AMD didn't mention anything about 3D V-Cache, their method for adding, well, three dimensional vertical cache for Ryzen 7000 to expand the Level 3 cache already on the die. Integrated graphics were one of Intel's last major differentiators prior to their E-core P-core layout change, because previously this required you to give up some cache and PCI Express bandwidth on Ryzen APUs. Well, now, all desktop Ryzen CPUs will have integrated graphics just like Intel. Can we get rid of the term APU now, then? (tropical music) Great! AMD didn't comment on just how many compute units would be included, but they did say that AM5 motherboards could come with any combination of up to four HDMI 2.1 or DisplayPort 2.0 outputs, likely in the form of USB Type C ports, which AMD will support in force, with up to 14 20 gigabit per second USB ports. By contrast Intel's top NZ690 chipset can only run four of those with the rest of them being 10 or 5 gigabit per second. That chipset's integration of Wi-Fi 6E is also no longer an Intel exclusive advantage, since the new AM5 platform natively supports Wi-Fi 6E with Bluetooth LE 5.2, and all of these features are going to be available across all of the new chipsets. AMD's actually shaken things up a little bit, by the way, with respect to their chipsets. What we might have previously thought of as X670 is now X670 Extreme, and it extends PCI Express Gen 5 to every available slot on the motherboard for ridiculous overall system bandwidth, something that Intel Z690 doesn't do. Vanilla X670, meanwhile, limits Gen 5 operation to just M.2 storage and the graphic slot, connecting those directly to the CPU like Intel does. Finally, there's B650, which defaults to PCI Express Gen 4 for all but the storage slot, which does get the Gen 5 treatment. There's no word on future A-series chipsets but, at least according to AMD's presentation, these are the only major differences between the chipsets that they did announce outside of power delivery, which is really more down to the motherboard manufacturers, anyway.
